summary: European Strategic alliance for research, development and innovation on medical countermeasures against CBRN threats
content: European Strategic alliance for research, development and innovation on medical countermeasures against CBRN threats

objective:
The EU is facing security challenges as CBRN threats especially of intended origin. It is thus critical that Europe develops relevant capabilities through medical countermeasures for which today very few are approved for use and available to European armed forces. The RESILIENCE project aims to build a European collaborative ecosystem against current or future CBRN threats, including research institutes, universities, RTOs, hospitals, industries, mid-caps and SMEs. It will be based on a multiannual action plan of research and development activities established in consultation with relevant authorities leading to effective and efficient medical countermeasures. Such countermeasures would then be industrialized, transferred and used by the armed forces for improving EU preparedness for CBRN military crises and fostering EU sovereignty.  
The main concept of the RESILIENCE multiannual action plan is based on a time-related deployment of armed forces in a theatre of operations where multiple health conditions requiring MCMs may occur. The action plan is organized around three main pillars of MCMs: Diagnosis, Prevention/Prophylaxis and Treatment which will respond to chemical (nerve agents, yperite, ricin and abrin), biological (pox viruses, viral hemorrhagic fevers, Y. pestis, B. anthracis, B. pseudo mallei and Botulinum toxins) and radiological and nuclear threats. Innovative diagnostic tools (e.g., on-field tools), novel vaccines (e.g., antibody-based, vaccine with high cross orthopox protection efficacy) and more efficient treatments (e.g., decorporating agents, reactivators of cholinesterases, phage therapy) will be developed.
By gathering a critical mass of European players who will collaborate to provide European armed forces with novel efficient MCMs, RESILIENCE will contribute to strengthening the autonomy of the European sovereignty, to developing EU autonomous industrial segments and to maintaining the operational capacity of soldiers in the field.

summary: European Packaging for highly Integrated Circuits for Reliable Electronics
content: European Packaging for highly Integrated Circuits for Reliable Electronics

objective:
State of the art high performance electronics are at the heart of nearly all defence products. However, the specificities of these products do not allow a straightforward use of civilian electronics. Therefore, mastering advanced packaging technologies and architectures is key to produce world-class defence products. 
EPICURE aims at giving Europe the means to master its future in advanced packaging. EPICURE will generate and integrate knowledge in advanced packaging technologies and architectures, perform the related studies and designs and prepare the supply chains to offer integration solution compatible with severe defence constraints and low volume production.
New trends in integration beyond Moore law are based on Heterogeneous Integration. EDA and DG studies have confirmed the need to develop advanced packaging technologies and shared Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test services (OSAT) in Europe, as the most advanced technologies are located in Far East or in US and are not accessible or under usage restriction. 
The project will analyze use cases requirements and constraints, and combine these towards modular architectures based on future chiplets. Elementary technological bricks such as advanced substrate down to 15µm L/S, wafer level packaging, Die to Die interconnect IP will be developed to build a “packaging toolbox”. Design engineering concerns will be addressed to identify the design flow, the design and assembly rules to build a “Physical Design Kit”. Five technology demonstrators will be designed, manufactured and tested to prequalify the toolbox. 
The aim is to develop in Europe OSAT and technology providers in the field of advanced packaging serving defence needs. These ambitious goals are achievable because the partners will bring advanced technologies i.e. advanced wafer level packaging from IZM, die-to-die interconnect from Extoll, new interposer for RF from UMS, heterogeneous integration packaging and test from Synergie CAD.
freeKeywords: Technology to merge a lot of electronics components in a single package
system or sub-system for more integration
power consumption savings and higher performances

summary: European Non-Line-of-Sight Optical Imaging
content: European Non-Line-of-Sight Optical Imaging

projectObjective:
The ENLIGHTEN project aims to develop disruptive technologies for next-generation electro-optical (EO) sensing devices which enable vision of scenes hidden behind obstacles. With this future sensing approach, ENLIGHTEN pushes the development of advanced concepts, promising technologies and innovations to the benefit of operational effectiveness. Moreover, the project supports the EU strategic autonomy and its freedom of action. Further, the project aims at stimulating cross-border cooperation of legal entities and fostering a better exploitation of the industrial potential of innovation, research and technological development. ENLIGHTEN can significantly boost the performance of future capabilities. 

ENLIGHTEN overcomes the current limitations to the line-of-sight of EO imaging by providing the capability to sense around obstacles onto scenes hidden from direct view. This non-line-of-sight (NLOS) technology is a game-changing capability, with the potential to improve the competitiveness, endurance and survivability in different operational scenarios. ENLIGHTEN improves NLOS technology from a laboratory demonstration level to relevant demonstration in terms of accessibility of building block technologies (sensor, laser source), data processing (algorithms) and demonstration setup. 

The main technical challenge of this project is to develop new NLOS algorithms and technology such as a SPAD camera and laser illuminator that work in the short-wave-infrared (SWIR) regime. By transferring the technology to operate in the SWIR regime, we will make it eye-safe, stealthy, and less affected by weather conditions, thus lifting many of the current limitations of current VIS approaches. Further, application of a SPAD array will reduce data acquisition time and therefore enables application in military relevant dynamic scenarios. We intend to bring the current technology readiness level (TRL) of 2/3 to TRL 5.
title: European Non-Line-of-Sight Optical Imaging

summary: European Military Integrated Space Situational Awareness and Recognition capabilitY
content: European Military Integrated Space Situational Awareness and Recognition capabilitY

objective:
EMISSARY proposal gives a comprehensive response to the growing dependency and threats facing space infrastructure, which are vital for global positioning, navigation, intelligence, and secure communications in military operations. 
The EU Council Conclusions on the EU Space Strategy for Security and Defence underscore the importance of Space Domain Awareness (SDA) for national sovereignty and encourage sharing SDA information among Member States. EMISSARY aligns with these conclusions, aiming to support the establishment of a complete and independent European military SSA value-chain. 

EMISSARY’s value proposition focuses on four interconnected beacons: sovereignty in detection, tracking, and characterization of space objects; shared European recognized space picture to sMS based on enhanced SSA data; integration into the international landscape; and establishing a robust European data security policy. It emphasizes the development of a network of advanced sensors and a military SSA Command and Control (C2) software to process and circulate data, ensuring national and European sovereignty while fostering EDTIB collaboration.

The project involves government agencies, industries, SME and midcaps, scientific communities and RTOs, and integrating international initiatives and innovative technologies. It encompasses 51 partners from 13 Member States, 12 of which has signed the Letter of Intent, ensuring continuity and expansion of expertise from previous projects like INTEGRAL and SAURON. EMISSARY aims to achieve a prototyping, demonstration and qualification stage for a large set of the technologies developed, reflecting a commitment to advancing European military SSA capabilities, ensuring security and sustainability in space, and enhancing Europe's strategic autonomy and international competitiveness in the space domain.

summary: European Innovative GaN Advanced Microwave Integration
content: European Innovative GaN Advanced Microwave Integration

objective:
The scope of this activity AGAMI_EURIGAMI is the strengthening and further development of the European GaN technology and components capability for defense applications. The project covers the critical areas of the complete supply chain starting from epitaxy up to the component packaging and integration in modern electronic defense systems. The main activities are related to the technology improvement and an improved resilience against electrical and environmental threads. Various demonstrator activities are envisaged to test innovative design concepts and to prove its success with MMICs coming from leading European industrial and research wafer manufacturing lines. The integration of the components in the systems is essential to achieve best microwave and mm-wave performance but it needs to protect the sensitive GaN device against the harsh environment in which defense systems need to operate.
The consortium consists of 34 partners from more than 10 different European countries. The partners are ranging from Europeans best research institutes and universities, involving major suppliers of critical materials, leading edge European wafer fabs with strong emphasis in developing advanced GaN technology, various design houses with unique skills and, finally, all European key defense system providers. This big initiative shall allow the European defense industry to grow its capabilities and to make an important step forward towards advanced multifunction and highly robust electronic systems for future defense systems. The project idea and the consortium have been initiated with strong involvement of various European Ministries of Defense (MoDs). It is going to become a major initiative in Europe and shall stand in line with various previous important activities like KORRIGAN, MANGA, EUGaNIC, MAGNUS, MUSTANG, etc. with the clear ambition to strengthen the European capability for GaN Advanced Microwave Integration.

summary: European Initiative for Collaborative Air Combat Standardization
content: European Initiative for Collaborative Air Combat Standardization

objective:
Air collaborative combat will involve future combat air systems, manned or unmanned platforms, legacy platforms and their evolution, including sensors and effectors. The EICACS project aims at ensuring the interoperability of such assets (with NATO and potentially other coalitions situations) and a seamless integration of future combat air systems.
 	The goals of the EICACS project are twofold :
	The first one is the promotion or development of design rules and interoperability standards :
	to ensure the interoperability of heterogeneous systems (future air combat systems, legacy platforms and unmanned assets)
	to support secure sharing of resources (sensors, effectors) and exchange of information (e.g. situational awareness, raw data) between those systems and platforms for the benefit of the mission execution and performance
	to offer mission system software scalability to speed up integration of new capabilities
	to define functional and physical interfaces of effectors
	to define functional interfaces of sensors
	The second one is the assessment of questions brought by the implementation of AI technologies aboard (in order to support the handling and exploitation of generated information as well as manned and unmanned mission management)
	Airworthiness and safety issues with AI based functions onboard
	European sovereignty over AI engineering tools, algorithm libraries and methods enabling the use of AI in military assets
	Compatibility of tools and processes for AI driven operational services (e.g. dynamic tasking of assets, decision-making support, data routing processes) to confirm feasibility and airworthiness.
 	The consortium of the EICACS project gather more than 30 companies, institutions, universities, midcaps, SMEs in 11 countries showing a large interest from the European landscape.

summary: European Future Highly Mobile Augmented Armoured Systems 2
content: European Future Highly Mobile Augmented Armoured Systems 2

objective: This proposed project, European Future Highly Mobile Augmented Armoured Systems 2 (FAMOUS2), aims at maximizing synergies, standardization and interoperability of armoured vehicles to address highly demanding requirements, while introducing innovation and promising new technologies and concepts, and reducing life cycle costs. EDF FAMOUS2 focuses on the study, design, testing and prototyping of the targeted vehicles and their novel sub-systems that can be considered as independent technology building blocks. The project is based on the identified capability requirements and identified operational needs of the participating nations. The project forms a continuum with the ongoing EDIDP FAMOUS project (selected under the EDIDP 2020), thus continuing the work begun during this precursor project. This continuum will optimize an efficient uptake of the ongoing EDIDP FAMOUS project outputs towards the downstream activities performed in the framework of EDF FAMOUS2, for the benefits of targeted vehicles development aiming at addressing armed forces’ needs during the next coming years. Moreover, the development of platform-agnostic technology building blocks provides synergies across several types of vehicles, strengthen harmonization of needs and interoperability, address armed forces needs in a medium-term timeframe while seeking innovative solutions across several key domains for future generations of ground vehicles. EDF FAMOUS2 develops indeed a next generation armoured platforms and upgrade and modernisation of existing platforms: design, prototyping and testing of future all-terrain vehicle (ATV) and light armoured vehicle (LAV), as well as upgrading Main Battle Tank (MBT) with 360° situational awareness system and active protection.

summary: European Extended Mine Countermeasures (E=MCM)
content: European Extended Mine Countermeasures (E=MCM)

objective:
The maritime mine threat is a reality for both the civil and military shipping since more than a century and the consequences can be ranged from blocking access to harbours, coastal waters and specific maritime areas to hindering drastically maritime trade and the freedom of manoeuvre of naval ships. In EU, the sea mine threat has been a constant – although changing – reality for decades and it is crucial that the EU Allies strengthen their capacities to counter effectively mine threats appearing in broad maritime spectrum zones that encompass surf zone to deep water including chokepoints, SLOCs delivering enabling essential trade such as communications, and energies to EU citizens, companies, governments. In that context, the European Extended Mine Countermeasures (E=MCM) project aims to close development gaps for capabilities of the Toolbox 2.0 by delivering better, faster, safer and more resilient MCM operations by designing, prototyping and demonstrating a single consistent system of systems (SoS) composed of: (i) advanced evolving & scalable unmanned autonomous toolboxes; (ii) intelligent platforms and decision support tools to achieve significant operational gains in terms of quality, performance and efficiency; (iii) incremental capabilities to address and counter, with increased effectiveness, the current and future mine threat ((drifting, tethered, and buried mines).

The consortium of E=MCM project is composed of 21 beneficiaries from 11 EU nations with 9 large companies, 2 Midcaps, 6 SMEs and 4 RTOs and the work is structured into 12 WPs: 3 WPs are related to studies, 4 WPs are related to Design activities, 4 WPs to Prototyping activities and 1 WP related to Testing activities.  
7 sea trials will be conducted across the overall EU (BE, NL, FR, DE, ES) and the total eligible cost of the E=MCM project is 69,87M€ with 45M€ from EU grant and 23,87M€ from 10 supporting EU Member States (BE, DE, EL, ES, FR, LT, LV, NL, PT, SE)

summary: European Detect & Avoid System, phase 2
content: European Detect & Avoid System, phase 2

objective:
This project addresses the EDF-2023-DA-C4ISR-DAA topic “Detect and Avoid” (DAA), technologies that enables Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems (RPAS) to integrate safely into non-segregated civil and military airspace, avoiding collisions with other aircraft. The DAA system observes the environment surrounding the Remotely Piloted Aircraft (RPA), detects traffic, assesses the risk of collision, informs and provides suggestions to the Remote Pilot (RP) to remain well clear and, when appropriate generates a new flight path to avoid collision. This way, DAA enables the RPA, or Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS), to operate along with other manned and unmanned aircraft, allowing a much more flexible use of RPAS/UAS than today, in order to train for, and conduct, security and defence missions in peacetime, crisis and conflict.
The European Detect and Avoid System - Part 2 project (herein abbreviated “EUDAAS2”) will complete the development of the DAA system for RPAS, designed and validated in the EDIDP 2019 Part 1 (herein abbreviated “EUDAAS1”), delivering (via EUROCAE) a full suite of required DAA standard updates supporting the provision of the ETSO baseline (by EASA), for the future system certification and product industrialization phase. 
The project’s Mission, as defined by the EDF-2023-DA-C4ISR-DAA topic scope, is to provide a fully standardised, qualified and certifiable DAA solution for UAS. The DAA solution should aim at fully integrating RPAS in the general airspace (A-G classes) without any limitations regarding operation in the airspace including in TMA.
The EUDAAS project runs over 4 years and is executed by a core the team maintained from EUDAAS1, supported by 5 contributing Member States and additional 6 nations cross-border partners. The team consist with a mix of with Defence and Aeronautics Industry groups, Aerospace Research Institutes, SMEs/MidCaps and Eurcontrol as the intergovernmental ATM organisation of Europe.

summary: European Defence Operational Collaborative Cloud
content: European Defence Operational Collaborative Cloud

objective:
Major industrial actors of Defence in Europe have joined efforts in the EDOCC project to develop a disruptive approach for the exchange of multi-domain services. The objective is to provide EU and Member States a virtual platform based on Cloud technologies that will increase the interoperability, efficiency and resiliency of military operations. This initiative will strengthen collaborative services on the battlefield and will support PESCO project ECOWAR. Airbus, Thales, Leonardo, Rheinmetall, Indra and Saab will closely cooperate on EDOCC federated
system together with selected partners complementing their portfolio (such as ATOS, MBDA and platform manufacturers) and several innovative European companies including SME. EDOCC project phase 1 presented in this offer will last 3 years and will be dedicated to study, design and conceptually validate the virtual platform and develop the first version of a service catalogue while identifying appropriate standards and technologies for high performance and interoperability.
Airbus will coordinate the project in close coordination with the core team partners that are sharingresponsibilities of various EDOCC activities across four pillars: OPS, IT, Network and Security.
The deliverable of the project is composed of study results, architecture and functional design, and a proof of concept through test laboratories that will be deployed in different countries. During the project, we will provide EU and Member States a clear understanding of the federated environment and the technical building blocks to be developed and integrated. 
Our intention for phase 1 is to demonstrate the benefit and added value of the virtual platform for multi-domain operations before the end of 2025, in order to prepare phase 2 and a complete EDOCC prototype horizon 2028.

summary: European Cyber Situational Awareness Platform - Enhanced Cyberspace Operations
content: European Cyber Situational Awareness Platform - Enhanced Cyberspace Operations

objective:
ECYSAP Enhanced Cyberspace Operations (ECYSAP EYE) will conduct a new development spiral for the Cyberspace Situational Awareness and Situational Understanding (CSASU) capability initiated by EDA contracts (CySAP) and a precedent EDIDP phase (ECYSAP). This new spiral will introduce novel functionalities that responds to additional end-user requirements, Concepts of Employment (CONEMP) of additional member states, and further adaption to the continuous and evolving understanding of how operationalize cyberspace in the context of multi-domain operations. ECYSAP EYE aligns with the needs expressed in the European Union Military Vision and Strategy on Cyberspace as a Domain of Operations, being a key piece for EU CSDP Command and Control (C2) under the PESCO EUMILCOM project. Its increased level of ambition focalizes in:
•To orchestrate reasoning and projection on the perceived mission-centric cyber pictures by Mission Engineering (ME) processes, which allows exploring dependencies between cyber assets and mission context while facilitating analysts in developing customized intelligence products to assist military decision-makers. 
•To assist human beings for their more in-depth comprehension of cyberspace regardless lacking of advanced cyber skills and customized to their area of interests, operations and responsibility. ECYSAP EYE explores cyberspace activities in a continuum of conflicts that intermingle military but also civilian actors, and where cyber situations may present physical, virtual or cyber cognitive nature.
•To transition from a purely defensive posture to understand changes in cyberspace as opportunities, assessing related effects not only in terms of mission assurance (which ECYSAP EYE will also make evolve from EDIDP phase) but also opportunities. ECYSAP EYE will cover specific developments for contributing to ISTAR (Intelligence, surveillance, target acquisition, and reconnaissance). 
•To achieve a more sophisticated development of options, differentiating passive measures from proposals that confront enemy decisions in the physical, virtual and cognitive spheres. ECYSAP EYE provides tailored guidance on how to response threatening situations and/or exploit opportunities. 
•Architectural transition to a System of Systems (SoS), which benefits include easing holistic capability understanding, more effective resource sharing/pooling and adaptation to different Force/C2 structures and procedures.

ECYSAP EYE is an EU sovereign initiative motivated by all defence capability boosting directions indicated by the EU Heads of State or Government as a consequence of Russian aggression to Ukraine (Versailles, March 2022). Passively contributes to 2) step up cooperation through joint projects; 3) close shortfalls and meet EU capability objectives; 4) boost innovation, including through civil/military synergies; and 5) strengthen and develop EU defence industry, including SMEs.

summary: European Counter Unmanned Aerial Systems
content: European Counter Unmanned Aerial Systems

objective:
E-CUAS aims to the design and development of CUAS solutions for countering class I UAS, single and/or multi-UAS, including military grade UAS such as loitering munitions by integrating multiple technologies for the effective protection of critical defence infrastructure, installations and assets in fixed, mobile and deployed scenarios.
The proposed CUAS solutions will integrate a) relevant passive and active sensors technologies to detect, track, classify the threats, including the capability of detection for non-cooperative and autonomous UAS.  b) a suite of soft kill and hard kill effector technologies with an optimal selection and activation of relevant effectors with a broad set of ROE adapted to the surrounding environment and the operational scenario. c) Command and Control (C2) capabilities supporting minimum operator effort for decision making, effective sensor and effector engagement according to ROE. d) networking and communications infrastructure, cyber security and interoperability data models and protocols for standard interfaces and interoperability with relevant foreseen UAS systems (e.g. U-space) and higher air defence C2 or other units.
The E-CUAS project is in continuity and complements the project JEY-CUAS awarded in the frame of the call EDIDP2020. The E-CUAS project will study, harmonize and consolidate concepts of operations, use cases, user needs, and operational requirements; deliver harmonized system requirements and standardized CUAS open architecture and interfaces; deliver CUAS solutions system/sub-system design; deliver CUAS solutions prototypes tested and qualified in relevant defence scenarios agreed with Member States.
Four large E-CUAS demos in defence scenarios are planned in Italy, Spain, France/Belgium, Germany of CUAS for protection of critical infrastructure, forward operating base and mobile assets. A security scenario in a civilian urban context for the protection of large events in public areas is also addressed.

summary: European COmon SupplY chain for Sovereign T2SL and infrarEd Modules.
content: European COmon SupplY chain for Sovereign T2SL and infrarEd Modules.

objective:
Infrared technology is an important element of Europe’s technological sovereignty in key value chains. T2SL detectors are expected to represent a large part of the infrared detectors market in the near future since they can address the entire infrared wavelength range, have an excellent quantum efficiency and array uniformity and operate at high temperatures, allowing for more compactness, lower energy consumption and cost-efficiency. Yet European detector manufacturers who want to propose T2SL products currently need to rely on non-EU industrial sources at least for substrate and epitaxy. 
ECOSYSTEM will consolidate a fully European supply chain for the next generation of high performance T2SL infrared detectors for defence applications. The project will address four main building blocks through: 
1-	Establishment of a European supply chain for GaSb epi ready substrates
2-	Establishment of a European epitaxy supply chain for the main wavelengths for defence applications 
3-	Development of a common post-processing ROIC bumping compatible with the selected advanced CMOS technology node 
4-	Design of improved cryocoolers with SWaP-C optimisation. These results will be demonstrated through prototypes.
Finally, ECOSYSTEM will offer a roadmap to assess the next required steps for strengthening the supply chain. The supply chain will be based on cooperative R&D, will be open to all European detector manufacturers and will target the next generation of high-performance infrared detectors for defence applications in all battlespace dimensions. 
ECOSYSTEM is fully aligned with European priorities as the project will contribute to maximise operational advantages, reinforce European autonomy and support the competitiveness of the European industry.

summary: Ensuring Circularity of Soldier Personal Protection Equipment
content: Ensuring Circularity of Soldier Personal Protection Equipment

objective:
UTILE project aims at developing and demonstrating several technologies that allow the implementation of circular strategies to 
recover and reuse of different soldier personal protection equipment (SPE) used by the different European national armies. 
These technologies will be clustered into three, 
i) Digital tools that allow the tracking of materials flows in the supply chain and to support in the stakeholders of the value chain in 
taking the proper decision. 
ii) Technologies that let the upcycling of current SPE products (mechanical and chemical recycling) exploring also new uses of the 
materials recovered for different application in the defence sector. 
iii) Technologies that help to reduce the environmental impact during the manufacturing process by fostering the use of more 
ecofriendly processes and sustainability by replacing petrol based materials by biobased ones. 
UTILE innovations have high disruptive potential: bio-based resins for recyclable fibre composites, novel aramid fibre carding and 
spinning processes for recycled yarn production, innovative UHMWPE defibration, filament production and 3D printing technologies, 
novel pre-preg production employing bio-based resin and recycled aramid fibres. These will be demonstrated in 3 case studies. 
In parallel to this technological and material innovations, UTILE is developing a digital platform including artificial intelligence (AI)-
based Decision Support Systems (DSS) and blockchain technologies for traceability, as well as circularity, environmental and costbenefit analysis (CBA) considerations in order to provide a holistic circular approach at EU level to the SPE value chain. The aim of the 
platform (named EU-level Circular Management System, EUCMS) is to foster the development, implementation, demonstration and 
validation of circularity concepts, first to the SPE value chain, but with the potential and intention to be transferred to other value 
chains in the Defense market.
projectObjective:
UTILE project aims at developing and demonstrating several technologies that allow the implementation of circular strategies to 
recover and reuse of different soldier personal protection equipment (SPE) used by the different European national armies. 
These technologies will be clustered into three, 
i) Digital tools that allow the tracking of materials flows in the supply chain and to support in the stakeholders of the value chain in 
taking the proper decision. 
ii) Technologies that let the upcycling of current SPE products (mechanical and chemical recycling) exploring also new uses of the 
materials recovered for different application in the defence sector. 
iii) Technologies that help to reduce the environmental impact during the manufacturing process by fostering the use of more 
ecofriendly processes and sustainability by replacing petrol based materials by biobased ones. 
UTILE innovations have high disruptive potential: bio-based resins for recyclable fibre composites, novel aramid fibre carding and 
spinning processes for recycled yarn production, innovative UHMWPE defibration, filament production and 3D printing technologies, 
novel pre-preg production employing bio-based resin and recycled aramid fibres. These will be demonstrated in 3 case studies. 
In parallel to this technological and material innovations, UTILE is developing a digital platform including artificial intelligence (AI)-
based Decision Support Systems (DSS) and blockchain technologies for traceability, as well as circularity, environmental and costbenefit analysis (CBA) considerations in order to provide a holistic circular approach at EU level to the SPE value chain. The aim of the 
platform (named EU-level Circular Management System, EUCMS) is to foster the development, implementation, demonstration and 
validation of circularity concepts, first to the SPE value chain, but with the potential and intention to be transferred to other value 
chains in the Defense market.
title: Ensuring Circularity of Soldier Personal Protection Equipment

summary: Enhancing cross-border CBRN operational readiness and effectiveness through an overarching System of Systems approach
content: Enhancing cross-border CBRN operational readiness and effectiveness through an overarching System of Systems approach

objective:
The main idea of CBRN SoS (System of Systems) is to design an overarching information system that can integrate different existing national CBRN defence information systems and components in a modular and flexible way. It can be permanently stationed in a specific configuration of core components ready for on demand deployment. Additional elements from different Nations can be added dynamically depending on specific needs of the operation. 
CBRN SoS addresses Detection, Identification and Monitoring (DIM), Knowledge Management (KM), Physical Protection (PP), and Hazard Management (HM). First an EU CBRN solution inventory study for these components will be conducted. These results will be analysed to identify capability improvements in existing information systems and map out synergies between Member States to define potential entry points for the federated CBRN SoS. Subsequently, the detailed system architecture design will be derived, and key representative parts prototyped to validate the system through demonstrations.
The main advantages of CBRN SoS result from the ability for multiple entities from different Member States to collaborate which enhances the overall situational awareness and leads to a faster and more efficient CBRN threat response. 
Using ATP 45 elements as key pillars for the distributed CBRN SoS software architecture, is an attempt to bring a well-established and known system structure into the fragmented landscape of isolated CBRN solutions. In this way different Nations can relate and map own structures to CBRN SoS more easily, which eventually improves the recognizability and identification of end-users with CBRN SoS. Rather than developing a completely new software solution from scratch, CBRN SoS uses the more efficient and more realistic approach to focus on interfaces to existing solutions and modules, as Member States want to continue using their own solutions and providers but still be able to cooperate in a federated way.

summary: Enhanced Pilot Interfaces & Interactions for fighter Cockpit
content: Enhanced Pilot Interfaces & Interactions for fighter Cockpit

objective:
To create Air power new capabilities and ensure Air dominance to European Armed Forces, EPIIC project aims at tackling the huge technological challenges of the future air warfare and the collaborative combat by identifying, assessing and developing highly innovative technologies and disruptive interactive modalities to be integrated into future fighter cockpits.

A future air combat pilot shall supervise all the platforms (manned/unmanned) under his responsibility in a highly complex environment.

This context will require in particular, disruptive concepts of human-machine cooperation using new technologies to create a completely immersive environment and a symbiotic teaming between systems and pilots. As some tasks will be performed automatically by machines, pilot will focus his resources on high value fields of action, thereby improving combat effectiveness.

That’s why EPIIC will study and develop some key fighter cockpit–related technologies such as, adaptive HMI, Innovative Virtual Assistant interaction, Large Area Display, Innovative and sovereign Eyes-Out technologies (Helmet Mounted Display and Canopy projection), disruptive Crew monitoring systems and new multi modal interactions. By nature those technologies shall be platform agnostic as requested in the Call Air Combat EPE.

The EPIIC team is made up of more than thirty organizations from twelve European countries. The team encompasses major industrial tier-one companies from FCAS and Tempest teams (Airbus Group, Dassault Aviation, Indra, Leonardo, Saab and Thales) but also University Research departments, innovative start-ups and mid-caps: all the best-in-class of the European competences.

EPIIC will foster European cross border cooperation to achieve European technological autonomy. Some clear dependencies to third party technologies have been already identified in legacy fighter cockpit avionics and EPIIC has the ambition to eradicate them or at least to mitigate them as much as possible.

summary: Energy Independent and Efficient Deployable Military Camps
content: Energy Independent and Efficient Deployable Military Camps

objective:
Deployable military camps are almost 100% dependent on fossil fuel, which represents a high environmental footprint and a vulnerability for the armed forces. Growing energy consumption of military equipment and energy transition/Green Deal are also new trends. 

INDY aims to develop a strategic roadmap towards the future energy independent and efficient deployable military camps, based on a paradigm shift for energy production, conversion, storage, transport, distribution and final usage. Building on (military and civilian) EU and national projects, INDY provides
1/ requirements for energy independent and efficient systems for deployable military camps, 
2/ methods for defining a common approach for interoperability, security, risk, cyber protection and life cycle 
3/ tools for planning, simulation, optimal control and camp energy digitalisation 
4/ evaluation of the best available and disruptive technologies and systems for the entire energy chain and for all energy usage 
5/ a modular architecture for energy systems, adaptable and demonstrated for four different use cases. 

INDY will be the first step to increase the security of energy supply and autonomy of deployable military camps and support their full transition towards renewable energy sources. The roadmap shall seek to reduce the usage of fossil fuel by 40% in 2030 (compared to 2020) and to reach 100% fossil fuel independency in 2050. INDY is a first step leading to an implementation roadmap, which could be used to set-up a full-scale operational demonstrator of a deployable camp fulfilling interoperability between inter-allied armies and NATO. 

INDY will be implemented over a period of 26 months by 28 entities from 13 EU countries and will seek to reinforce cross-border cooperation in the field of energy independent military camps beyond the project lifetime. As a result, INDY will contribute to enhance the competitiveness and innovation capacity of the EU defence industry in the area of new energies.

summary: Efficient Autonomous multirole drone Guard for criticaL infrastructures surveillancE missionS
content: Efficient Autonomous multirole drone Guard for criticaL infrastructures surveillancE missionS

objective:
Russia's high-intensity war in Ukraine has made the European Union countries aware of hybrid attacks and the tactical importance of drone swarms for both offensive and defensive purposes. For the emergency management and military operational capabilities of EU nations, the complete real-time awareness of the scenario is crucial to increase mission effectiveness and enable risk mitigation actions. In this context, unmanned platforms can be the best option thanks to the absence of a pilot that makes them “expendables” in harsh environments (i.e., nuclear plant disaster, large fire events) or war scenarios.
The intrinsic limitations of convenient small and cheap solutions, like the reduced autonomy and the poor capability in terms of data transmission and computational power can drastically reduce the attractiveness for missions requiring the ground stations being very far from the target location (i.e., nuclear plant disaster or heavy combat scenarios). These weaknesses can be overcome by implementing a sort of “unmanned flying bridge” able to operate as a communication bridge between the small drones flying over the target and the ground station, carrying and releasing the swarm of drones in a location close to the target to maximize the efficiency of the mission by exploiting the whole mini-drones’ autonomy, coordinating the swarm in an automatic or semi-automatic way.
The goal of the EAGLES project is to fill the current design and technological gaps, by performing studies and conceptual design activities on the “flying bridge“ and by studying technologies that will facilitate the development of a System of Systems, nowadays not present on the market, that will give EU defence actors the capability of collecting data and gain information for prompt and effective decision making at low costs and reduced risk.
More in details, EAGLES will focus on the development of communication technologies for both hardware and software, artificial intelligence techniques to manage the mini-drone swarm and to process data acquired by mission sensors, and autonomous flight techniques to assure the drop and rendezvous of mini-drones.

summary: EUropean Cyber and INFormation warfare toolbox
content: EUropean Cyber and INFormation warfare toolbox

objective:
Information warfare can be defined as the deliberate use of information to achieve specific objectives over adversaries. Although this concept was already described in the 5th century BC by the Chinese military strategist Sun-Tzu in “The Art of War”, the increasingly widespread use of internet and social media has emphasised its importance in recent years’ conflicts.

EUCINF will study, design, prototype, test and demonstrate cutting-edge capabilities in the domain of Cyber and Information Warfare through a toolbox. i.e. a holistic system which embeds

(1) a coherent set of components that covers the full data lifecycle from data management (collection, processing, storage and indexing) to CIW-intelligence (situation awareness, capitalisation of threats and known actors, mission management and countermeasures)
(2) an Interoperability Framework and its associated TestBed which define and validate data exchanges and interfaces between components to ensure the constitution of operational toolchains
(3) a Store able to host components and their associated metadata allowing capitalisation within EU stakeholders while avoiding unnecessary duplication of work
 
Emerging technologies, notably based on AI, will be explored with respect to current standards and regulations, social and cultural impacts; and ethics considerations. Three scenarios and use cases will support the design of the proposed EUCINF toolbox, including tools, methods, data, and common functions for integration in defence systems such as i.a. standards, interoperability, trustworthiness, and ethics as addressed in dedicated WPs. It will be based on EU-owned solutions/technologies. An End User Group will be set and integrated in an Agile Approach.

EUCINF benefits from a well-balanced consortium with key European capabilities and skills: European champions in AI, platform manufacturers, effectors, systems developers covering the whole spectrum of CIW related applications.

summary: EUROpean Goal based mUlti mission Autonomous naval Reference platform Development
content: EUROpean Goal based mUlti mission Autonomous naval Reference platform Development

objective:
Recent geo-political developments and related security challenges have accentuated the need for rapid response capabilities by well-coordinated EU naval vessel fleets with advanced platform and weapon systems’ technologies. 
In line with the EDF call and PESCO MSASV project,  EUROGUARD will  integrate innovative EU technologies into a demonstrator vessel (as a system of systems), approximately 40m in length and able to carry several modular mission modules to demonstrate, in a representative environment, autonomous operation for a number of coastal concepts of operations including ISR. In parallel to this,  a Generic European Naval System Architecture (GENSA) based on MBSE and applicable to future European autonomous naval vessels will also be showcased. One of the key innovations within the project will be the controlled autonomous decision-making (ADM) allowing unmanned onboard systems to perform missions in total autonomy. To enable the development of all the required functions, a data-centric dataflow architecture and Edge AI backbone software architecture especially adapted to remote-controlled/autonomous vessels will also be developed within the project.  Through these demonstrations, EUROGUARD will enable EU navies to further explore the feasibility and possibilities offer to them by the use of MSASVs either working independently or as part of a national or coalition fleet operation as well as the potential opportunities that will open up to them, including a reduction in on-board crew numbers. EUROGUARD’s success is guaranteed by the quality of the cross border partnerships and the ability of leveraging civil-defence cross-fertilization from leading European industrial enterprises in the consortium. EU-wide benefit is guaranteed by dissemination actions and physical demonstrations up to TRL7-level.

summary: EUROPEAN INTERACTIVE SENSOR-BASED DYNAMIC DEFENCE NETWORK
content: EUROPEAN INTERACTIVE SENSOR-BASED DYNAMIC DEFENCE NETWORK

objective:
Today’s EU Integrated Air and Missile Defence (IAMD) sensor centric weapons systems need to be improved to increase their resilience and reactivity against the emergence of new threats and the repercussions that they have. These new threats are stealthier, faster, greater in number, and more agile by their manoeuvrability. The combination of those threats used in synchronized strikes often confuse and saturate current IAMD weapon systems.
The NIAG Working group 260 (NATO Industry Advisory Industry Group) recommended that IAMD suppliers should move away from a sensor centric to a network centric approach through the creation of a network of FCCs and sensors referred to as a ‘sensor grid’ which would allow real time sharing of data and services between sensors in a highly dynamic and efficient manner. 
In this way improvements in operational performance are achieved through a combination of fast data rate dynamic sensor tasking, data fusion, and the effective distribution of services in real-time (below a second) over the dynamic decision-making sensor grid. It obtains the benefit of the multiple sensors coverage, resources and data combined  while accelerating the exchange of information up and down the control and command chain.
The overriding ambition of the project is to define the EISNET architecture framework tool (EAFT) that will consist in a set of common concepts, rules and functions that will permit the scalability of heterogenous weapon systems, sensors and FCC with different architectures or configurations cooperating in a network centric solution. To achieve this, FCC and sensor suppliers will have to implement progressively and seamlessly these concepts, rules and functions in their systems to be compliant with the EAFT. Heterogeneity of technologies often considered as a weakness of the European defence market will become a benefit through the combining of these different sensors, weapons and FCC and use them as a unified system while preserving their autonomy and sovereignty in usage and on key technologies. This is a new tactical advantage as the attacking threats are faced with uncertainty while the diversity of systems with real-time dynamic tactics management contributes to an ever better resilience.
projectObjective:
Today’s EU Integrated Air and Missile Defence (IAMD) sensor centric weapons systems need to be improved to increase their resilience and reactivity against the emergence of new threats and the repercussions that they have. These new threats are stealthier, faster, greater in number, and more agile by their manoeuvrability. The combination of those threats used in synchronized strikes often confuse and saturate current IAMD weapon systems.

summary: EUROPEAN DIGITAL NAVAL FOUNDATION
content: EUROPEAN DIGITAL NAVAL FOUNDATION

objective:
EDINAF proposes to launch the digital revolution for Naval Industry by developing fundamentals
enabling this transformation through:
➢ the development of a reference ship digital architecture offering a coherent set of resources, services and data solutions supporting the warship’s core operations,
➢ a digital platform specification as the standardized IT infrastructure derived from the reference architecture considering common base services to be offered to user applications on new generation warship´s development
➢ A new digital engineering adapting processes, methodologies and tools requested by an ever evolving and highly complex interdependent System of Systems
During the 3 years project, EDINAF will work on 4 Blocks identified as being essential on the path to this digital transformation:
➢ Block 1: Identification of digital capabilities due to be provided by the core IT infrastructure for the Digital Warship
➢ Block 2: Definition of the Digital warship core reference architecture, IT infrastructure and Demonstrator
➢ Block 3: Identification of Digital Engineering Models for EDINAF using Model-Based Systems Engineering
➢ Block 4: Building a transversal developer platform for use cases integration and demonstration

summary: EU Next Generation Rotorcraft Technologies Project.
content: EU Next Generation Rotorcraft Technologies Project.

projectObjective:
ENGRT is a R&T project aiming at breakthrough progress on EU military rotorcrafts.
A first major axis will consist in understanding and analysing EU MoDs future needs. This work will be performed through a pan-European work on future rotorcraft CONOPS, supported by Battlefield Simulations.
Effects of key future rotorcraft features and capabilities, at Mission, Field of Operations, and global fleet level will be assessed. Conceptual and pre-design of alternative rotorcraft platforms will be performed. High speed rotorcraft technology demonstrators, flights and related flight simulators will be offered. Outputs to this first research axis will mainly consist in a mature understanding of future needs, several alternatives of aircraft vehicle designs potentially answering, as well as a clear pan-EU military rotorcraft technology roadmap answering the 2030+ and 2040+ horizons.
In support of the first Research axis on CONOPS and assessment of vehicle alternatives, the second Research axis will be focused on EU Technologies necessary for next generation rotorcrafts:
-	on systems : EU-wide consensus on Modular Open System Architecture, compatibility to EU Systems of Systems, as well as systems specifications
-	on structure : addressing the whole Life-Cycle, we will investigate modular structure concepts, use of new manufacturing techniques, multi-functional structural elements, and advanced maintenance concepts
-	power architecture and power plant : working on the right power architectures for new platforms, as well as defining pan-EU positions on zero-emission / carbon-neutral technologies , and defining likely needs for next generation rotorcraft engines.

ENGRT is expected to play a pivotal role on future EU rotorcraft upgrades, and on the definition of a new generation of EU military rotorcrafts.

summary: EDF-2021-EPW
content: EDF-2021-EPW

objective:
Against the backdrop of increasing security threats for satellite communications, the focus on joint CSDP missions between EU nations and the ambition for growing EU autonomy, 19 key stakeholders in the EU military satellite ecosystem have joined forces in a consortium to start the development process for the European Protected Waveform (EPW). The capability gap for the EPW was already identified in different EDA and EU reports (KSA, CARD) 
In this EPW proposal the consortium will focus on the Study and Design phases in the development process for a multi-layered security and resiliency solution that consists of an EU protected waveform standard, software defined baseband equipment and 
adjacent security technologies. Under the umbrella of the adjacent security technologies are EPW considerations for on-board processing satellites as well as study and design work on next-gen satellite terminals for on-the-move applications (e.g. UAVs), small satellites and upcoming technologies such as 5G, Hybrid networks, etc.). The main objective is to present the military end-user with an innovative end-to-end secure solution for seamless satellite communications at maximum information assurance. 
The European Protected Waveform is built around four corner stones: efficient, secure, affordable and interoperable satellite communications and will be accessible to small, mid-sized and large European nations seeking to embrace today’s and future challenges related to increased throughput demand over satellite, dispersed operations, mobility and new security threats. 
The EPW consortium will maximize synergies with other EU programs such as ESSOR, ENTRUSTED and upcoming EU initiatives focusing on GovSatCom and secure connectivity capabilities (EU LEO Constellation) where the EPW could be integrated. 
This proposal is based on an original proposal during EDIDP 2019: EDIDP-PNTSCC-SCC-2019 proposal 004 EPW

summary: Digital Supply-Chain for On-Site Maintenance in defence by Additive Manufacturing
content: Digital Supply-Chain for On-Site Maintenance in defence by Additive Manufacturing

objective:
The DISCMAM project aims to revolutionize the capabilities of deployed military forces by harnessing the power of metal Additive Manufacturing (AM) technologies and creating a new digital supply chain. Currently, military operations face significant downtimes due to maintenance requirements of equipment, vehicles, and other critical assets, heavily relying on repair and spare parts supply. By leveraging metal AM technologies, the project seeks to enable rapid response in manufacturing metallic spare parts and repairing critical components, regardless of the operational location.
The EU defence sector has yet to fully exploit the potential of AM technologies, mainly due to the lack of highly skilled personnel available during military deployments. DISCMAM addresses this challenge by developing a secure and disruptive digital thread, facilitating remote assistance for repair and spare parts manufacturing in military field operations.
Through two demonstrative use cases utilizing Powder Bed Fusion and Directed Energy Deposition Laser-based technologies, DISCMAM will validate its innovative solution. The digital thread will establish an effective digital supply chain for on-site maintenance within the EU defence sector.
The project brings together new actors in defence research and innovation, laying the foundation for an innovative business model that enables remote-assisted on-site maintenance operations. DISCMAM will provide autonomy to repair damaged components and manufacture spare parts through secure communication pathways. Key benefits include eliminating the need for AM highly specialized operators/technicians on-site, reducing supply time, shortages, and spare parts costs, minimizing non-usage time of critical assets, and optimizing on-site stocks and digital inventory.
DISCMAM marks a significant step forward in enhancing the self-sufficiency and operational efficiency of deployed military forces, thereby reducing logistical costs and vulnerabilities. This project is dedicated to empowering military personnel and ensuring their readiness and effectiveness in both warfighting and peacekeeping missions.

summary: Digital Ship Structural Health Monitoring
content: Digital Ship Structural Health Monitoring

objective:
The dTHOR project will develop next generation predictive Ship Structural Health Monitoring (SSHM) systems. These systems will be
based on innovative utilisation of large amounts of load and response measurements from robust and advanced sensor systems, a
digital framework complying with recognised open standards for data exchange, and hybrid analysis and modelling (HAM) which
combines physics-based and data-driven models. These tools will be applied to achieve interoperable and evolving models
facilitating a game change for SSHM.

dTHOR will consolidate end-users’ military operational requirements based on improved battle damage and structural integrity
assessment, reduced hydro-acoustic signatures, and more accurate operation of weapon systems.
By delivering the above-mentioned predictive capabilities, the dTHOR project will enable; a) A holistic approach to complete lifecycle
management from design to decommissioning; b) Effective transition from traditional time-based to condition-based maintenance;
c) Increased operational availability and increased levels of safety; d) Continuous optimisation of operational performance in peace
time and war time/crisis situations; e) Game-changing speed of knowledge transfer between Research, Innovation, Design and
Operations (the digital RIDO-concept).

The dTHOR consortium is characterized by diversity and complementary of partners from 11 Member states/associated country with
8 SMEs, 4 mid-caps, 5 leading shipyards and altogether 35 partners. The development of a SSHM system based on open standards
agreed upon by a strong pan-European consortium representing the whole supply chain helps to support cross-border cooperation.
Finally, we emphasize the importance of the proximity to the naval end-users via the 5 naval shipyards located across Europe, the
consortium is in a good position to integrate their requirements, lessons learned and feedback.

summary: Development of intelligent military capabilities for monitoring, medical care and evacuation for contagious, injured and contaminated personnel
content: Development of intelligent military capabilities for monitoring, medical care and evacuation for contagious, injured and contaminated personnel

objective:
The situation of ground forces has seen paradigm changes, which also affect the provision of medical care. In any future battlefield, ground forces will cover more extensive areas. Combined with highly dynamic location changes and greater reach of military intelligence as well as an increasing threat of CBRN scenarios, the requirements for the medical environment have risen substantially, especially as the time between injury and support measures must be as short as possible. In addition, the medical care unit in the field cannot be as close to the personnel in the field as this was the case in the past. This poses challenges to the transport chain, which needs to be quick, flexible, coordinated, autonomous, and ideally unmanned.
Despite unmanned ground and aerial transport and en-route care chains have been discussed for years, no such solution has been realised yet. iMEDCAP will provide the design and component level proof-of-concept validation of an integrated solution to detect, extract, transport and remotely provide first support to highly injured and possibly contaminated personnel. This is realised in a fully unmanned setup, making transport capacities easier to scale, while significantly saving medical staff resources.
The iMEDCAP solution will comprise the following activities and technology developments to realise this solution: a user-driven scenario definition taking into account possible CBRN threats as well as recent mission experience, the design and development of autonomous detection of injured personnel, automatic definition of an evacuation and rescue strategy, involving UGV and UAV as needed, both unmanned, and an interoperable patient box, equipped with diagnostic and intervention equipment which can provide initial measures during transport under remote control. The final outcome will be validation of the components and a roadmap for further development, laying the foundation for a modern and digital European Rescue system.

summary: Detect and Recognize Mines and IEDs hidden in the environment
content: Detect and Recognize Mines and IEDs hidden in the environment

objective:
The DeterMine (Detect and Recognize Mines and IEDs hidden in the environment) project is targeted to generate knowledge and to contribute to the strengthening of the EU knowledgebase and creation of the standardised benchmarks for evaluation of the landmine and IEDs detection systems, to ultimately pave the way for enhanced protection of personnel and infrastructures and freedom of actions for military forces. 
DeterMine aims to achieve this goal by using the technological challenge to verify the concept for a modular multisensory and multiplatform solution for hidden threats detection and identification,  gathering and sharing data from the test fields and working on data improvement by applying AI and data fusion techniques, pursuing as an overall objective the improvement of the major metrics: detection accuracy and hidden threat classification and feature estimation. 
The project is driven by an incremental approach allowing to test different technologies, sensor combinations and data fusion algorithms.

The project is driven by an incremental approach allowing to test different technologies, sensor combinations and data fusion algorithms.

summary: DePloyable Special OpeRations FOrces MulTi Environment CommAnd Post and C2 System (SFCPC2) — PROTEAS
content: DePloyable Special OpeRations FOrces MulTi Environment CommAnd Post and C2 System (SFCPC2) — PROTEAS

objective:
Joint Operations that involve Special Operations Forces (SOF) are rapidly becoming a very important instrument for MoDs worldwide and across Europe. It is evident that symmetric and asymmetric threats inside and outside the EU territory require fast response and the ability to rapidly deploy transportable units implementing a Special Operations Forces - Command Post (SOFCP) to areas of interest, during both peace and wartime. 
PROTEAS project aims at providing a prototyped deployable SOFCPC2 consisting of the following parts: (a) the SOFCP shelter that will be air/sea/ground transportable, rapidly deployable  and resilient to  adverse  operational and weather conditions; (b) the SOFCP Power system that will be a military grade, autonomous, horizontally scalable and low thermal/acoustic signature system capable of furnishing the energy needs of the entire SOFCP; (c) the SOFCP interoperable and cyber-secure communications infrastructure that will enable the exchange of information across the entire command hierarchy; (d)  the multiple domain Command and Control (C2) capable of supporting operations related to intelligence gathering from various sources, analysis and further dissemination of them towards enhanced situation awareness; (e)  the portable devices for field-deployed SOF task groups providing C2 and DACAS functionalities at the tactical edge; (f) the manned and unmanned assets, employed either for transportation of SOF Task Groups or the collection of intelligence and (g) the SOFCP perimeter security system capable of detecting ground threats near the camp . The proposed project will cover all necessary study, design, system prototyping, testing and validation actions required to engineer a state-of-the-art prototyped SOFCPC2 to support SOF operations in SJO missions. To the best of our knowledge, this will be the first European effort to develop a SOFCPC2, making PROTEAS envisaged impact being of paramount importance both in national and EU level.

summary: DEvelopMent of Enabling technologies for a THust-vectored hypersonic vehicle featuring innovative combustoR and mAterials
content: DEvelopMent of Enabling technologies for a THust-vectored hypersonic vehicle featuring innovative combustoR and mAterials

objective:
Hypersonic weapons have the potential to revolutionize warfare and accelerate the achievement of European defence air superiority, especially in the current geo-political situation. In this scenario, supersonic combustion jet engines (scramjets) make it possible to achieve very high speeds at long ranges and with high flexibility. Actually, the scramjet technology is perceived as the key solution to cover large flight Mach number envelopes up to Mach 10-12 and even further. However, scramjets face many technical difficulties that need to be solved before they can enter regular service, in particular: 1) aerodynamic heating of the vehicle which at such high speeds becomes hardly manageable and undermines structural integrity; 2) reliable and efficient burning of the fuel, especially when transitioning from hydrogen to hydrocarbon-based fuels, which are more suitable for defence applications as they are safer, more storable and provide more readiness for deployment in the context of military applications; 3) the capability to change and control the thrust direction is key to promote tracking and interception of attacking threats, but at hypersonic flight speeds, the efficiency of conventional aerodynamic control surfaces is limited due to the shocks around the vehicle.
In DEMETHRA, three novel scramjet-enabling technologies will be investigated that can solve the above-mentioned main challenges: 1) innovative porous ceramics carbon-composite materials for transpiration cooling and fuel injection, 2) propellant injection and flame holding devices for hydrocarbon-based fuels and 3) thrust vectoring by means of jets and ramps in the nozzle. These technologies will be assessed using both numerical and experimental studies on a highly modular model that will be tested in a hypersonic wind tunnel laboratory, with the aim of de-risking potential future exploitation of the investigated technologies and provide an invaluable database for validation of proposed concepts.

summary: Cyber-secure weArable, ultra-low-Power networked SensoRs for soldIer health monItoring.
content: Cyber-secure weArable, ultra-low-Power networked SensoRs for soldIer health monItoring.

objective: The CAPSARII project proposal aims at developing an innovative smart textile/wearable device and related ICT framework to display raw health data and Machine Learning (ML)-derived insights, designed specifically for military staff, which aligns with the concept of the Internet of Battlefield Things (IoBT), driven by Artificial Intelligence (AI) and edge computing, aiming to transform the monitoring of soldiers' psychophysical conditions and the evaluation of their performance, both in combat and training scenarios, thus allowing for real-time health status assessments through a specialized ML model. In the face of the challenges posed by an increasingly unstable world, the European Defence Agency has recently revised its Capability Development Plan (CDP) to reach new levels of preparedness and cooperation among the member countries. Among the 11 priorities identified in the CDP, improving ground combat capabilities requires enhancing the equipment of individual soldiers to obtain better protection. Fine grain-awareness of the physiological and psychological status of each soldier can be a key tool for making sound tactical decisions, as well as to provide life-saving information to medical support services. Wearable System Integration, Edge computing, Cloud-based analytics and AI Model Optimization for Resource Constrained Systems are among the key technological bricks at the foundation of the potential of disruption of CAPSARII project.

summary: Covert and Advanced multi-modal Sensor Systems for tArget acquisiTion and reconnAissance
content: Covert and Advanced multi-modal Sensor Systems for tArget acquisiTion and reconnAissance

objective:
EU defence capabilities are confronted with fast-emerging challenges and highly adaptive threats in land, maritime and air domains. To ensure superiority, novel methods, concepts and multi-sensor platforms are needed for enhanced, covert target sensing and increased situational awareness. CASSATA intends to provide improvements in a whole range of Covert Sensing domains: 
1/ CASSATA will implement innovative technologies to improve the covertness of optronics sensors as well as their capabilities of detection, tracking, classification and identification 
2/ To CASSATA will study three types of sensors (Acoustic/seismic networks for area surveillance, MEMS based acoustic sensors and Opto-acoustic sensors) that contribute to the network of sensors providing coverage for previously undetectable targets in challenging environments 
3/ CASSATA will implement innovative technologies and/or upgrade current technologies to provide covert RF sensors (radar and RF Direction Finding) or to improve their capabilities of detection and tracking for vehicles, sea surface targets, air targets (from low size drone to high speed targets). 
4/ In CASSATA, the use of new generation techniques (data fusion and collaboration techniques, Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning) will be applied to maximize the ISR capabilities of the sensing systems themselves, as well as those of the multi-sensing platforms/ Techniques, methodologies and solutions studied and designed in CASSATA will be tested and validated in appropriate simulation and/or laboratory environment following a use-case oriented approach. To achieve its objectives, CASSATA will unleash a large, inclusive & industry-driven consortium to provide more accurate and effective covert sensing solutions: 
• demonstrated under strict SWaP-C requirements
• enabling information superiority down to the tactical level 
• responding to a top priority of the EU Capability Development Pl

summary: Convoy Operations with Manned-unMAnNeD Systems
content: Convoy Operations with Manned-unMAnNeD Systems

objective:
The COMMANDS project aims to develop Through Life Capabilities (TLC) for agile, intelligent and cooperative Manned and Unmanned Land Systems. These Capabilities will be based on a variety of state-of-the-art UGV Technologies solutions that will provide seamless functional services across integrated modular open architectures. The answer to the UGVT call is based on a solid Systems Engineering process supported by a Technology Demonstrator and a Business Case, that will ensure early de-risking as well
as potential early exploitation of technologies directly addressing a roadmap of self-reliant EU Defence TLC sustainable development.
The results will not only enable to upgrade current ground vehicles of the EU inventory for specific missions, but also to be integrated in future vehicles in development. COMMANDS addresses the requirement of military unmanned ground vehicles to operate not only in controlled paved surfaces, but also in unstructured environments, facing degraded or denied satellite signal and
communications scenarios where the development of Computer Based Processing Technologies, Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence provide game changing Intelligent Capabilities.
The Technology Demonstrator Programme includes both a laboratory demonstrator and a real scenario Mobile Demonstrator centered around the used case of a Last Kilometre Re-supply Convoy with Force Protection. The capability services architecture are common to manned and unmanned platforms. enabling seamless, standard transition from manned to unmanned. The COMMANDS approach challenges the current state-of-the-art technology insertion, providing more efficient and effective cooperative intelligent behaviour and human-centred ethically aligned services in different Operational States and Environments, complementing mannedunmanned teaming. The proposal is developed in the context of PESCO project iUGS, and strongly aligned with the EU Ground Combat Capability Development Plan.

summary: ClOud iNtelligent explosiVe detectiOn sYstem
content: ClOud iNtelligent explosiVe detectiOn sYstem

objective:
The CONVOY (ClOud iNtelligent explosiVe detectiOn sYstem) proposal is based on the development and integration of a demonstrator that will evolve through the participation in four evaluation campaigns. The CONVOY demonstrator will consist of a set of different integrated components based on the following guidelines: Multi-sensor approach. Multi-platform approach. Artificial Intelligence and Information fusion. Integration into/with Command and Control Systems. Tactical Cloud: Open Architecture and Standards.

The solution proposed by the CONVOY consortium is based on the experience of other demining and IED detection projects, the knowledge from tactical cloud infrastructures and artificial intelligence and information fusion initiatives, the lessons learnt from multiple sensor data acquisition and fusion projects and the lessons learnt from Soldier Modernization R&D projects.

summary: CARMENTA PRIMUM FUGA
content: CARMENTA PRIMUM FUGA

objective:
This Project Proposal respond to the CALL EDF-2023-DA-AIR-SPS: Self-protection systems and is the follow-on of the EDIDP 2020 project CARMENTA (Carmenta Phase 1). The overall main objective of the whole Carmenta Project is to Design, Develop, Verify, Validate, Qualify and Certify a future and innovative Self Protection System (SPS) that will increase the survivability of fixed-wing and rotary-wing, combat and non-combat aircrafts, in a hostile environment. The present proposal constitutes a second phase of the Carmenta Project and aims to design, prototyping and testing of such new generation system. The proposed project, starting from the results of the CARMENTA Phase 1 project, will proceed with the Subsystems Detailed Design categorized in three classes: High Development Item (HDI) with major technological improvements, Low Development Item (LDI) with minor technological improvements and Non-Development Item (NDI) limited to implementation of features to make them compatible with Carmenta ecosystem.

The innovative technological improvements will be verified, at subsystems and system level, by means of a Demonstrators that will be tested in a laboratory environment with an appropriate set of stimuli and monitoring. After that in order to step up to TRL 7 the design will be updated as necessary and a Prototype, for all or part of the subsystems will be realized, integrated and installed in an existing rotary wing aircraft made available by the Italian Air Force, and a Fight Test campaign will be carried. In addition, a digital model of each subsystem will be designed and developed, to be integrated in a simulation engine of overall system to support analysis and for evaluation of its behaviour when operate in different scenarios and in different configurations.

summary: Autonomous SSA Bodyguard Onboard Satellite
content: Autonomous SSA Bodyguard Onboard Satellite

objective:
BODYGUARD aims to develop building blocks for autonomous SSA capabilities onboard satellites. The included studies will address both use cases of hosted SSA-payload as well dedicated guardian satellites. A sensory system will be designed to detect incoming threats in far and close distances. Onboard processing system will be designed to enable fully autonomous AI-based threat detection, identification, tracking, maneuver recognition and self-protecting action decisions. Countermeasure robotics will be designed to handle physically attacking threat with resilience added to equipment like optics and comms to ensure partial operation under engaged distant threat. This project will complement previous EDF SSA projects by autonomous onboard SSA systems developments, empowered by AI for self-protection needs. BODYGUARD will be able to classify the types of manoeuvres being made from far distance thus rising an alarm early. In close proximity, it can detect weak-points of the threat satellite and counteract with a robot or laser. Detection is accomplished using AI onboard processing from multiple sensor inputs, including highly sensitive optical greyscale and IR cameras with various FOVs, laser ranging and LiDAR systems. Self-protection actions are based on high-intensity laser beam, microwave and high-voltage applications as well as a micro-robot that rendezvous to a weak spot of the threat satellite to disable it. 

The EDF-2023-RA-SPACE-PSA grant allows to perform knowledge generation, studies and design activities. Therefore BODYGUARD will accomplish development-targeted research activities up to TRL4 and TRL5. Technology concept studies through this project will lead to deeper competency in SSA sensors, detection capabilities and protective actions to be taken (e.g. designing autonomous sensors with AI-processing that can be added to GEO-satellite or its In-Orbit-Servicing module and will alarm host satellite about approaching threats).
